Introduction

Somatic dysfunction is an impairment in bone, joint, muscle, and fascia function, with subsequent effects on the neurovascular and lymphatic systems.  Identifying and treating somatic dysfunction is fundamental to osteopathic medicine treatment.

Definition and pathophysiology

Definition



Somatic dysfunction is defined by the mnemonic TART:



  • Tissue texture changes:  These can vary widely depending on acuity (discussed below).
  • Asymmetry:  The interconnectedness of tissues can create imbalances manifesting as asymmetry of anatomical landmarks.
  • Restriction of motion:  Normal physiologic motion is limited by anatomical barriers (eg, bone structure) and physiologic barriers (eg, ligamentous tension, muscle tone).  In somatic dysfunction, restrictive (ie, pathologic) barriers limit range of motion (well before anatomic/physiologic barriers are reached).
  • Tenderness:  Pain that is disproportionate to the amount of pressure applied, most significantly during acute dysfunctions (although also present to a lesser degree with chronic dysfunctions).

Pathophysiology



Somatic dysfunction is believed to result from neuromuscular imbalance and abnormal sensory input, particularly from mechanoreceptors and nociceptors.  The dysfunction usually occurs due to an underlying injury, although it can also be due to visceral inflammation.



A major contributing factor to somatic dysfunction is facilitationâ€”a state of sustained subthreshold excitation of spinal interneurons that leads to exaggerated motor and autonomic responses.  This heightened responsiveness results in persistent muscle tone changes, restricted joint motion, and autonomic dysregulation.  Facilitation via the spinal reflex occurs as follows:



  • Sensory (afferent) input:  Injury to a somatic structure (eg, muscle, joint) activates mechanoreceptors and nociceptors.  For example, injury to the bicep muscle activates muscle spindle fibers that send increased afferent signals to the spinal cord at the C5-C6 level.
  • Spinal pathway:  Continued afferent input from the injured tissue sensitizes interneurons in the spinal cord.  These interneurons mediate communication between afferent and efferent pathways and become more easily activated over time.
  • Motor (efferent) output:  When interneurons are sensitized, a lower-than-normal threshold of sensory input is sufficient to trigger somatic motor neuron firing.  This results in sustained hypertonicity of the injured muscle (eg, bicep) and nearby muscles that share the same spinal level (eg, cervical paravertebral muscles).


This process contributes to persistent muscle tone changes, joint restriction, and autonomic dysregulation.

Acute vs chronic somatic dysfunction



Differentiating between acute and chronic somatic dysfunction is important for diagnosis and treatment planning (

).

Acute somatic dysfunction



During the acute stage of somatic dysfunction (days to weeks following injury), pain occurs due to the initial damage and resulting release of inflammatory mediators (eg, histamine, prostaglandins) that produce local vasodilation.  Therefore, TART findings include erythema, bogginess (ie, edema), hypertonic muscles, and significant tenderness to palpation.  Movement at the restrictive barrier of affected joints causes pain, limiting active range of motion.

Chronic somatic dysfunction



In the chronic stage of somatic dysfunction (weeks to months following injury), tissue remodeling develops as the acute inflammatory response transitions to a chronic, fibrotic response due to the release of profibrotic mediators (eg, transforming growth factor beta).  Chronic pain also causes local vasoconstriction due to sustained, increased local sympathetic activity.  Therefore, TART findings include cool skin and pallor, ropy and stringy tissue, decreased muscle tone, and limited active and passive range of motion (due to fibrosis/contracture).

Laws of spinal motion (Fryette)



The laws of spinal motion (Fryette) (

figure 1
) describe patterns of vertebral sidebending (coronal displacement about an anteroposterior axis) and rotation (transverse displacement about a vertical axis) in the thoracic and lumbar spine, helping guide the diagnosis and treatment of somatic dysfunction.  These laws do not apply to the cervical spine, which has its own set of rules (discussed in a separate article).

First law



When the spine is in a neutral position (ie, no significant flexion or extension), sidebending and rotation occur in opposite directions.  This applies primarily to groups of vertebrae (eg, T10-T12).  For example, if a patient's lumbar spine sidebends to the left in the neutral position, it will rotate to the right.

Second law



When the spine is in a nonneutral position (flexed or extended), sidebending and rotation occur in the same direction.  This applies to a single vertebral segment.  For example, if L3 is flexed and sidebent left, it will also rotate left.

Nomenclature for somatic dysfunctions



Somatic dysfunctions are named based on the position of the structure in relation to its freedom of motion, rather than its restriction.  Spinal dysfunctions are named by the vertebral level involved (eg, T3, T6-T8) and position of ease (ie, the direction in which the vertebra moves most freely).  For example:



  • T3-T5 NSLRR:  Vertebrae T3-T5 are in neutral, sidebent left, and rotated right (a group dysfunction following the first law [ie, type I dysfunction]).  On palpation, the transverse processes are more posterior on the right when the spine is in the neutral position, and the asymmetry becomes less pronounced with flexion or extension.  No improvement is seen with flexion or extension.
  • T3 FRSR:  T3 is flexed, rotated right, and sidebent right (a nonneutral dysfunction following the second law [ie, type II dysfunction]).  On palpation, the right transverse process is more posterior when the spine is in a flexed position, and the asymmetry worsens or does not improve when the spine is extended.

).  Somatic dysfunctions for other structures are also named in relation to freedom of motion.  For example, in rib exhalation dysfunctions, the ribs are stuck in exhalation (ie, restricted in inhalation).

Clinical relevance and treatment implications



Somatic dysfunction is often implicated in a variety of systemic and regional conditions, including:



  • Musculoskeletal pain (eg, back and neck pain).
  • Headaches (eg, tension, cervicogenic).
  • Postural imbalances and gait abnormalities.
  • Visceral conditions (eg, appendicitis presenting with T12-L2 somatic dysfunction).
  • Gastrointestinal dysfunction (eg, constipation, postoperative ileus).
  • Respiratory disorders (eg, asthma, pneumonia).


Acute somatic dysfunction typically responds with relative ease to techniques that are indirect (eg, counterstrain, indirect muscle energy).  In contrast, chronic dysfunction may require more persistent and deeper techniques (eg, direct muscle energy, high velocity low amplitude).  These techniques are discussed in a separate article.

Summary



Somatic dysfunction is characterized by impaired function of the musculoskeletal system and associated neurovascular and lymphatic structures, clinically identified using the TART criteria (Tissue texture changes, Asymmetry, Restriction of motion, Tenderness).  Its underlying mechanism involves neuromuscular imbalance, facilitation, and spinal reflexes that sustain muscle hypertonicity and joint restrictions.  Differentiating acute from chronic somatic dysfunction guides therapeutic decisions, influencing the choice of indirect versus direct osteopathic techniques.
